issue.title: ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY in Pre-built Chromium binary
issue.body:
I see a warning about a weak key: ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY, when connecting to test servers.
![pic1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717541-706bf200-752e-11eb-928e-b0239f03b32e.png)
It’s happening with all signature algorithms supported by OQS-enabled Chromium build 0.4.0, except ecdsap256 and rsa3072. The secure connection symbol is missing on server page.
![pic2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717578-7e217780-752e-11eb-9a56-e9284048a266.png)
Also the "subject public key" field in certificate details is empty. 
![pic3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717601-85488580-752e-11eb-838a-899533cd9d79.png)
Why does Chromium display that field incorrectly? What could be the problem and how to solve it?

comment.body:
Thanks for the additional clarification. Yes, it's clear that no algorithm other than those listed will work in that build. You would have to build&configure chromium (and boringssl) yourself to change that. 

In turn, using `p256_kyber90s512` correctly establishes a connection but "only" fails to show public key and recognize dilithium2 as a (classicly) "strong" signature algorithm? That rings a bell -- I do recall having changed some Chromium code to get rid of that problem. Let me dig though the repositories... Until then, could you please check using Ubuntu 19? For all I remember the chromium binary you are testing was built on that OS and it would be good to eliminate that as a cause for the problem.

![pic1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717541-706bf200-752e-11eb-928e-b0239f03b32e.png)
It’s happening with all signature algorithms supported by OQS-enabled Chromium build 0.4.0, except ecdsap256 and rsa3072. The secure connection symbol is missing on server page.
![pic2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717578-7e217780-752e-11eb-9a56-e9284048a266.png)
Also the "subject public key" field in certificate details is empty. 
![pic3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717601-85488580-752e-11eb-838a-899533cd9d79.png)
Why does Chromium display that field incorrectly? What could be the problem and how to solve it?

comment.body:
OK, found a way: 
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57787676/108994011-91058a80-769b-11eb-91c9-e2b58c250f90.png)

FYI, this does _not_ fix the inability of chromium to display the actual QSC key structures. That would probably require pretty deep modifications in the core chromium code.

May I ask what your goals are? Is basic acceptance of QSC sig algs in certs presented to chromium sufficient for those purposes?

issue.title: ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY in Pre-built Chromium binary
issue.body:
I see a warning about a weak key: ERR_CERT_WEAK_KEY, when connecting to test servers.
![pic1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717541-706bf200-752e-11eb-928e-b0239f03b32e.png)
It’s happening with all signature algorithms supported by OQS-enabled Chromium build 0.4.0, except ecdsap256 and rsa3072. The secure connection symbol is missing on server page.
![pic2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71976077/108717578-7e217780-752e-11eb-9a56-e9284048a266.png)
Also the "subject public key" field in certificate details is empty.

Why does Chromium display that field incorrectly? What could be the problem and how to solve it?

comment.body:
>May I ask what your goals are? 

I want to use quantum-resistant cryptography in my diploma thesis. 

>Is basic acceptance of QSC sig algs in certs presented to chromium sufficient for those purposes?

I think, that's more than enough.

issue.title: Enabling all signature algorithms by default.
issue.body:
In [ssl/ssl_local.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L207), there are `#define`s that assign one-hot encodings to each signature algorithm. These encodings are used in [ssl/ssl_cert_table.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_cert_table.h#L26), and are assigned to a uint32_t variable called `amask` [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L1924).

Since the encodings are one-hot, at most 32 different signature algorithms can be encoded, and since 8 bits are already used up by OpenSSL by default, at most 24 different OQS signature algorithms can be encoded and assigned to `amask` at any given instant. 

This (possibly?) prevents us from enabling all signature algorithms by default, and the question is how we should deal with this.

comment.body: Including all algs would mean that CI runs do test every single algorithm; right now, we manually enable and test all the algorithms before a release. It would also mean that users wouldn't have to go through the algorithm enabling process.

issue.title: Enabling all signature algorithms by default.
issue.body:
In [ssl/ssl_local.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L207), there are `#define`s that assign one-hot encodings to each signature algorithm. These encodings are used in [ssl/ssl_cert_table.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_cert_table.h#L26), and are assigned to a uint32_t variable called `amask` [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L1924).

Since the encodings are one-hot, at most 32 different signature algorithms can be encoded, and since 8 bits are already used up by OpenSSL by default, at most 24 different OQS signature algorithms can be encoded and assigned to `amask` at any given instant. 

This (possibly?) prevents us from enabling all signature algorithms by default, and the question is how we should deal with this.

comment.body:
> It would also mean that users wouldn't have to go through the algorithm enabling process.

Do we know users that need _all_ these algs? On which platforms? Wouldn't it be a better approach to have a "representative" set of algorithms enabled (similar to what we have now) and do "the full monty" with all algs only on release? All it'd need for the latter is running `sed` over the checked-in "representative" `generate.yml` to save us any manual effort _and_ save the CO2 emitted by CCI doing over-and-over the same tests.

As a concrete proposal: What about disabling by default all algs that don't truly "teach something new"? For example, why have SHAKE _and_ AES _and_ plain ref algs for the same family and NIST level? What about asking all algorithm "owners" about a priority list and then using that to curtail each family at the same count (say 1 alg per NIST level)?

issue.title: Enabling all signature algorithms by default.
issue.body:
In [ssl/ssl_local.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L207), there are `#define`s that assign one-hot encodings to each signature algorithm. These encodings are used in [ssl/ssl_cert_table.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_cert_table.h#L26), and are assigned to a uint32_t variable called `amask` [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L1924).

Since the encodings are one-hot, at most 32 different signature algorithms can be encoded, and since 8 bits are already used up by OpenSSL by default, at most 24 different OQS signature algorithms can be encoded and assigned to `amask` at any given instant. 

This (possibly?) prevents us from enabling all signature algorithms by default, and the question is how we should deal with this.

comment.body:
> Do we know users that need _all_ these algs? On which platforms? 

Not that I'm aware of, I just see this as a secondary nice-to-have. 

> Wouldn't it be a better approach to have a "representative" set of algorithms enabled (similar to what we have now) and do "the full monty" with all algs only on release? 

There's still a small chance we might not catch certain errors until release testing time, but this should be low as long as the algorithms are representative enough (which I've tried to ensure here and in OpenSSH). 

> As a concrete proposal: What about disabling by default all algs that don't truly "teach something new"? For example, why have SHAKE _and_ AES _and_ plain ref algs for the same family and NIST level? What about asking all algorithm "owners" about a priority list and then using that to curtail each family at the same count (say 1 alg per NIST level)?

When I took a shot at something like this last year, it was not well received, but we can revisit this.

issue.title: Enabling all signature algorithms by default.
issue.body:
In [ssl/ssl_local.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L207), there are `#define`s that assign one-hot encodings to each signature algorithm. These encodings are used in [ssl/ssl_cert_table.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_cert_table.h#L26), and are assigned to a uint32_t variable called `amask` [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L1924).

Since the encodings are one-hot, at most 32 different signature algorithms can be encoded, and since 8 bits are already used up by OpenSSL by default, at most 24 different OQS signature algorithms can be encoded and assigned to `amask` at any given instant. 

This (possibly?) prevents us from enabling all signature algorithms by default, and the question is how we should deal with this.

comment.body:
> Not that I'm aware of, I just see this as a secondary nice-to-have.

Then I'd say we take our responsibility for the environment more serious and run _all_ algs as rarely as reasonable.

> When I took a shot at something like this last year, it was not well received, but we can revisit this.

So maybe a topic for our call (@dstebila ?)

issue.title: Streamline CCI
issue.body:
Pursue the same optimizations as discussed in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/918

Proposals:
- CMS and speed testing only to be done at main merge (or in an audit branch)
- boringssl and "second" (shared/static, Linux/OSX) tests only run after manual approval (or in an audit branch)

Inviting particularly @jschanck for suggestions.
